html: Thank you for joining this #FridayFocus on the President’s budget and how Congress starts its appropriations process. Stay tuned for future updates as we continue crafting legislation that will fund the government in fiscal year 2020.

html: Congress holds the power of the purse and it is important that we craft a thoughtful budget that takes into account the needs of Americans – not just the desires of the President.

html: This is where the appropriations process comes in. Congress appropriates funding to different departments and each member can circulate and sign letters of support for programs, agencies, or priorities.

html: The Committee will convene regularly to receive updates on the direction of our government’s spending and how our annual budget can best reflect the priorities of our nation.
text: The Committee will convene regularly to receive updates on the direction of our government’s spending and how our annual budget can best reflect the priorities of our nation.

html: One of the Committee’s main responsibilities is to carry out oversight on budget proposals that are presented to Congress.
text: One of the Committee’s main responsibilities is to carry out oversight on budget proposals that are presented to Congress.

html: The Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 created the Budget Committee to allow Congress to develop a self-governing group of members to analyze the President’s budget proposal and unite it with congressional plans.
text: The Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 created the Budget Committee to allow Congress to develop a self-governing group of members to analyze the President’s budget proposal and unite it with congressional plans.

html: It’s important to note, though, that these are just suggestions. The budget is what the president *wants* programs/agencies/departments to be funded at – Congress reviews the wish list and changes it to reflect *its* own priorities.
text: It’s important to note, though, that these are just suggestions. The budget is what the president *wants* programs/agencies/departments to be funded at – Congress reviews the wish list and changes it to reflect *its* own priorities.

html: So, for example, if a president thinks affordable housing or the Special Olympics are good, positive things that the government should get behind, his budget proposal will include funding for the departments that oversee those programs.
text: So, for example, if a president thinks affordable housing or the Special Olympics are good, positive things that the government should get behind, his budget proposal will include funding for the departments that oversee those programs.

html: So, each year the President sends his proposed budget – what he would ideally like Congress to do – for members of Congress to review. A budget is like a statement of principles – a president’s budget will mirror a president's values.
text: So, each year the President sends his proposed budget – what he would ideally like Congress to do – for members of Congress to review.   A budget is like a statement of principles – a president’s budget will mirror a president's values.

html: Everything from the Department of Defense to the National Institutes of Health fall under the Executive Branch and each year funding levels must be set. However, the President does not have the power of the purse – the Constitution explicitly gives that authority to Congress.
text: Everything from the Department of Defense to the National Institutes of Health fall under the Executive Branch and each year funding levels must be set. However, the President does not have the power of the purse – the Constitution explicitly gives that authority to Congress.

html: The President’s budget is a (very large) document outlining the Administration’s policy priorities and how they ought to be funded. The document itself is very large because the Executive Branch oversees massive government agencies.
text: The President’s budget is a (very large) document outlining the Administration’s policy priorities and how they ought to be funded. The document itself is very large because the Executive Branch oversees massive government agencies.

html: Overall, the federal budget process is straightforward: in the spring, the president proposes a budget, Congress reviews that budget, and then Congress tries to agree on a final budget resolution.

html: When the #GOPFarmBill cuts $23 billion out of SNAP funding, they’re shaving dollar & pennies off the little assistance recipients have. If the GOP really wants to help working families get ahead, they’ll grapple with the reality of SNAP and stop trading in dangerous stereotypes.
text: When the #GOPFarmBill cuts $23 billion out of SNAP funding, they’re shaving dollar & pennies off the little assistance recipients have. If the GOP really wants to help working families get ahead, they’ll grapple with the reality of SNAP and stop trading in dangerous stereotypes.

html: Throwing stricter work requirements on jobs that may already be vulnerable or unstable and wasting their time with job training programs is destructive. It prevents recipients from getting home, receiving the food they need, and keeping their families fed. #GOPFarmBill
text: Throwing stricter work requirements on jobs that may already be vulnerable or unstable and wasting their time with job training programs is destructive. It prevents recipients from getting home, receiving the food they need, and keeping their families fed. #GOPFarmBill

html: The GOP would like to paint a picture of a luxury food assistance program that keeps Americans out of the workforce. The reality of SNAP is that the vast majority of adults who are required to work, do work, and are struggling to support their families. #GOPFarmBill
